title: Blood Moon Zyra Concepts
body:
Hey everyone! I've been playing a lot of Zyra lately and it's gotten me in the skin designing mood C: Some of you guys might remember the Mythic Zyra concept I designed a few weeks ago that picked up some traction! This time I'm sharing a Blood Moon / Lunar Revel skin idea for her.

The skin is inspired by Futakuchi-Onna, a form of Japanese demoness with two faces on the front and backs of their heads who would use their serpentlike hair to feed. In this skin, in lieu of plants, Zyra summons monstrous creatures made of her own living hair to do her bidding. In place of seeds, cursed combs erupt from the ground and sprout long tendrils of hair. Her Blood Moon mask is situated on the back of her head, like the Futakuchi-Onna's second face. I like the idea of the mask sort of possessing her body, and when she dies it rises alone in a mass of living hair, leaving its mortal shell behind. 

I thought it'd be a cool opportunity to explore a different direction for Zyra's player fantasy! Still a summoner of sorts but straying away from the plant thematic present in her other skins. I figure if Lissandra can throw knives and still talk like she's throwing ice then it's probably no big deal ;)

Here's the lineup of the concept sketches! 
https://41.media.tumblr.com/8c6ab9c406428c1fe9ff31d454b671ae/tumblr_o3qufgMNoV1qk32lpo6_r1_1280.png
And I'll post them by themselves too in case the resolution turns out better

https://40.media.tumblr.com/49413e8bacce51f976c6b0848c083fc5/tumblr_o3qufgMNoV1qk32lpo1_500.png

Let me know what you guys think! I had a lot of fun working on this one.

so what about making skin like this?

Zyra in her current state is a legendary amount of work to make a skin for, for a multitude of reasons. Also she is currently being adjusted for the Mage Update, so we want to see how she is changed. Yes, any skin we make for Zyra - even the SKT 750, takes about as much work as a Legendary skin for another champion. It's unfortunate but some of our complex champions are like this and we have to plan accordingly.

Heya, sorry about the silly question, but im interested. What about Zyra makes it so difficult to make skins for her? I do not own the skin, but from the skin spotlight, all that seemed to change was the model. Are there a lot of under the hood stuff that we cant see?

Yeah making skins, or developing content for games in general, is often much more involved than players account for. For example QA testing on a new skin involves sweeps on each existing skin, which compounds multiplicatively for the number of models a champion uses. Anything that needs to be localised like VO must be written, cast, recorded and processed for every region.

Without getting too bogged down, a skin for Mundo uses one model. Zyra has a model for herself, her passive, the seed, grasping plant, and thorn plant. Even on 750s animators often do Quality of Life sweeps, adjusting and improving the back catalogue so there's a lot of work that happens behind the scenes.

> [{quoted}](name=Kindlejack,realm=NA,application-id=A8FQeEA8,discussion-id=V8qMmuvY,comment-id=0022000000000001000000030000,timestamp=2016-03-15T18:09:13.736+0000)
> Even on 750s animators often do Quality of Life sweeps, adjusting and improving the back catalogue so there's a lot of work that happens behind the scenes.

Oh ok, thanks for clearing that up for me! Its cool to hear about all of the stuff in creation that we dont see.

No problem! If you have any specific questions about what goes in to making a skin ask away >:)

My role as a concept artist is to take an idea the Product Owners choose from words on a spreadsheet to a fully finished design with a strong thematic to support future skins. It's super challenging and can take a while because we get feedback from so many different sources and work collaboratively to ensure the best possible results. More recently we've been trying to work more flexibly alongside the other artists such as animators and character artists to test out ideas in-game faster which has been really great but really opened my eyes to the various limitations and challenges each discipline faces every time we do a skin.

Oh, that's super cool. So let me make sure I have this right; you have a list of ideas for skins that you are tasked with creating concept art for, and depending on the concepts, the upper ups choose which skins to go all the way? 

If that's the case, i'm sure that can be a hard job, but i'm also sure it is super rewarding if your's get picked. >:D

We often have open meetings where anyone can pitch ideas for skins, and often fan skins come up during these meetings. The objective is sometimes '____ needs a new skin', 'we need 3 champions to fit thematic ___' or 'we are looking for a new thematic to fit patch ____' so what actually gets discussed is often very different but always tactical.

After that most of what we do is working on a product that, unless there are good reasons, will actually ship in some form or another. Then we are tasked with taking a description like 'A LeBlanc skin that is druidic or fairy in theme' and turning it into a finished design which our team can a) get excited about and b) model, texture, rig, animate, vfx, sfx, QA and paint a splash for. The other big part of my job is following that process and having lots of conversations all the way up to promotional materials and splash story to make sure that what we get excited about at the very beginning comes through in every aspect of the product so that players really feel it.

It can be tough because as you say, we don't get to pick and choose what we draw and you'll be getting feedback from everyone at Riot that mains that champion. Sometimes it'll be a theme you're not too familiar with and you'll have to do a lot of research and play a heap of that champion to ensure you really understand what is exciting about that champion/theme and where you can add a lot of value for players. But it's really wonderful to see players enjoying the team's hard work, and personally I get so excited when I see fan art of a skin I got to work on >xD

Hey Kindlejack. Would you care to discuss the topic of skin-neglected champions that get new skins? Does this mean that all the time they went without getting a skin will never, for lack of a better term, be "made-up for" and despite the fact that they finally receive a skin, all the years they went without one will be "wasted?" Take Zed and Project Zed for example. Zed hasn't received an ***official*** skin since his release in November of 2012. He received Project late last year. Does this mean that he may potentially have to wait another 3 years for some love because he went so long without a skin?

To put it in other words: *Does the longer you go without a skin, mean you go even longer without a skin after you get one?*

I think it's a very interesting topic of discussion. Note that I'm not necessarily asking for anything here; I'm more interested in discussing the topic of skin-neglected champions that recently get a skin and what it means for them in the future and what it means for them for all the years they went without one.

Also please understand that I don't intend any bias. If Zed got 10 skins in one year, I would be complaining about it. Partly because of the obvious "other champs deserve it first" thing, and also partly because my wallet definitely wouldn't be able to handle that, lol!

Previous cadence is no indication of the time between future skins. If you take a look as Zed from a production standpoint:

November 2012: Zed released with launch skin, skin cadence ~65 skins per year so no skin expected for 12-16 months.
October 2013: SKT win Worlds S3 and Zed is chosen for an SKT skin (meaning no other Zed skin is being worked on at this time).
May 2014: SKT Zed is released.
November 2014: planning begins for PROJECT event and Zed is chosen to get a PROJECT skin.
September 2015: PROJECT Zed is released.

So while from the outside it might seem like Zed was 'neglected' it was never really the case. Over the past year, since I joined the team, our goal was to try and increase our cadence dramatically and try to ensure as many champions as possible received a skin. This year might turn out a little different, and we always prioritize champions that resonate well with a thematic over champions that just need a skin to avoid shoehorning, but my hope for the future of skins is to maintain a cadence that ensures champions are served appropriately and regularly. The only ones that get left out are those on the rework list, but after Poppy's awesome rework and the revitalisation of her back catalog I hope Champion Updates are also something players are excited about!

Awesome, that was very insightful. Sounds like a hard, but rewarding job. Thank you for talking the time to explain this stuff to little ol' me, I raise my glass to you. 

{{sticker:slayer-pantheon-thumbs}}
My pleasure! Thanks for playing LoL and asking some great questions so I can talk about what I do >xD

The thing about ideas we pass on or projects that get shelved or scrapped, is that we're never convinced they couldn't work in the future! But for this reason we don't talk about them publicly in the hopes that we can one-day solve them and do them the way we want to.

For example my very first concept I did when freelancing was not put into production, but I really hope it will some time soon. Another is Forsaken Jayce, which was originally concepted as one possible idea for a skin way back when the champion was being designed!
Who do you consider to be your most complex champions skin wise? Have you made any improvements in this regard? Take Zac for example.

I was surprised to learn that Bard is a huge amount of work for SFX due to his meeps, health relics and chimes having a lot going on. It's really a per-champion basis because some are really intensive because of their kit like Illoui and others because of their design like Jinx.

im not 100% positive, but anytime this question gets brought up, Cassiopeia due to her model just being weird to work with, Zyra due to her changing model and multiple plants, and Kha'zix with his evolving model are the 3 that get thrown out by different rioters.

Hey! I know it's been pretty common knowledge for a little while now that the champions up for the Mid Year Mage Update (tm) are not really being considered for skins because it would be a waste of resources to make new particles for a skin and then have to change them again if that champ gets a new spell.

However! Definitely Not Vel'koz was just put onto the PBE a few days ago, and if I'm not mistaken Vel'koz is definitely on the list for The Official 2016 Middle Of The Year Magic Wielder Game Play Updater (tm). Does this mean the other five champs on the list are still eligible for 750 RP skins between now and the update, or is this just a case of the Vel'koz skin was already so far in the works before he was decided to be part of the update that y'all just decided to sneak him anyway?

And this is the part of the post where someone makes a joke about "Wait, Vel'koz isn't getting a new skin! I don't know which champion you are talking about but it definitely isn't Vel'koz!"

You're right, a 750 generally isn't greatly impacted by kit changes (unless they get a new ability that adds geo) but DNV was also already in production when they began the Mage update - our production timelines are usually pretty long.

We try not to create headaches for the other teams. Sometimes it's unavoidable, PROJECT Fiora was in development at the same time as the Fiora update which created a lot of problems for both teams, but we try. So once we know there is an upcoming change to a champion's kit where it's more than just number tweaking we try to plan around that.
